reviewText:
So, I owned this game back on CD until that one broke, and when it appeared on Steam, it didn't take me long to make the decision to re-acquire it.
This game is one of the classics and my personal favorite of the series (maybe, mabye tied with Blood Money).
Don't expect HD graphics as the game is fairly old, but they still hold up and the gameplay makes well up for it.
The game mostly gives you free reign over how you deal with your missions, wether you go in guns blazing or infiltrate the building disguised as the milkman, take out your target and leave without anyone ever knowing better; the only consequence being a distinct shift in your overall mission ratings (though wether or not a Mass Murderer rating is good or bad is still technically up to you. *wink*).
What you have to know is that if you play it quiet, you play it slow. Be prepared to wait for good whiles to learn guard routes or for your target to be in the perfect spot; be prepared to reload often (if you're a perfectionist) when things didn't go as planned, or quickly adapt to your new situation.
So, overall, if you enjoy the thought of being the unseen angel of death that puts Altair and Ezio to shame, or if you played and enjoyed any of the other Hitman titles (and for some reason don't already have this one), this is a definite must-have.

reviewText:
The Hitman series is a piece of history.  I think this game was the fruition of the stealth/action genre, and its effective implementation have inspired dozens of other games, including Assasin's Creed. Hitman 2 is my favorite, not because it's the best, but because it was one of the first PC games I fell in love with. The atmospheric mood, soundtrack, and art stylization really drew me in and have greatly influenced what I look for in the medium. While the gameplay has dated, the effective combination of other aspects have kept it consistently in my top 20, even a decade later.

Gameplay: 5
In a post Assasin's Creed world, it has definitely dated.  At the time, however, the controls and AI were stellar.

Story: 6
Nothing revolutionary, but it serves to draw together the wide variety of locations presented in the game.

Art: 9
The mood and atmospheres are incredible. No other game at the time captured the diversity of worlds so well with so little graphically, justifying literally hundreds of hours of slow sneaking - without ever feeling dry or boring.  This combined with the music makes it a classic.

Music: 9
Jesper Kyd is a master. At a time when most games featured popish midi synth, he had his soundtrack was performed by the Budapest Symphony Orchestra.

Should you play this?
If you haven't played this before, you likely won't be impressed. But if you like classic games and want to see a bit of history, enjoy it for the fantastic environmental moods the game creators were able to capture. For those of you who enjoyed it 10 years ago, you'll appreciate a replay.

Title: Hitman 2: Silent Assassin
Genre: Action
Developer: IO Interactive

General Impression
Hitman 2: Silent Assassin is a stealth game, made especially for people who can keep silent. The graphics for the year 2002 are wonderful, the soundtracks are very enjoyable, the atmosphere varies from tunnels, buildings, cities and even more areas, also the countries vary, such as Russia, India, Sicily, etc. The gameplay is pretty much just to kill enemies, you have a lot of guns to choose from, such as pistols, shotguns, rifles, grenades and even melee guns, such as katanas, knifes, swords, etc. You can even get your enemy asleep for a period of time, with anesthetics. The story is about a Hitman who retired as a yard keeper, until the priest of the church got kidnapped by a Russian mob. He has to accomplish some tasks for his agent, Diana. After he accomplishes them all, he will have to fight through the church to kill the Russian mob and liberate the priest.

Graphics
The graphics are wonderful for the year 2002, a big improvement from the game Hitman: Codename 47. They are well optimized, and they are wonderful even on budget computers. They are set in natural destinations (such as Japanese mountains), where we may see snow, trees, rocks, etc. well designed. The guns seem to be well designed, as well as the sky, the buildings, in the city destinations. Even in tunnels, the graphics are still well optimized, not dark.

Atmosphere
The atmosphere varies from countries such as Russia, Italy, Japan, Afghanistan, India, Sicily and Germany. This game has many areas, such as subways, sewers, palaces, mansions, mountains, cities, deserts, etc. The variety of areas makes this game complex, proving that the developers had a lot of inspiration and were able to create a complex game. The weather varies from area and country, such as Afghanistan (desert) where it's sunny, or Russia (city) where it's snowy, etc.

Audio
The soundtrack of this game were composed by Jesper Kyd, a well-known composer for video games and movies. They tend to change often, such as if you have alerted the enemy, a shocky and dynamic music will play. If you are just making your way through, a calm music would play. reviewText:
Hitman 2 Silent Assassin is a game that one approaches with much anticipation. The original Hitman was a true classic and any follow up to that would have to be something extraordinary in order to meet the expectations.

As Silent Assassin starts out 47 has retired and now lives a quiet life, tending the gardens in a Sicilian monastery. This all changes rather dramatically of course as your friend and mentor is kidnapped and you are forced to once again, take on the role of a professional hitman.

The story in general leaves much to be desired and the extremely subpar voice acting does not to help it. The grating sound of foreign accents that might as well have all been done by the same American voice actor often takes you out of the game and it is a shame that the developers couldn't have sprung for a couple of authentic sounds along the way. The high quality soundtrack and some passable ambiance makes up for some of this shortfall but not all of it unfortunately.

In terms of gameplay nothing much has changed. You travel from mission to mission, picking your starting gear and then going about killing a preset target in whichever manner you find to be the most efficient. Silent Assassin introduces a new rating system at the end of each mission that rewards you based on performance. Unfortunately the highest rating you can receive is usually only given out for executing a mission in a very specific way and this makes it very counterintuitive to the otherwise very open-ended missions.

The mission areas are much bigger this time around and while this sometimes allow for more creative thinking in solving the missions it also tends to slow down the game's pace, particularly in missions where running might attract the attention of nearby guards.

The developers seems to have paid attention to some of the fan feedback of the original and Silent Assassin has now been given a save game system. Depending on your difficulty level you are given a certain number of saves each mission and while this is still a far cry from what really should be standard in PC games it is also a huge leap forwards from the complete lack of in-mission saves in the original. A number of new camera angles are also available to you at popular request.

Graphically Hitman is still a beautiful game, not quite as big of a step forward as one might have wanted, looking at what else is out there, but still good enough that it adds to the experience rather than detract from it.

All in all Hitman 2 Silent Assassin is a good game, even a good sequel, but in many ways it is also a bit of a letdown. It doesn't do much to advance the franchise instead sticking with what worked in the original and mostly rehashing what was already there. If you liked the original Hitman then you are going to like Silent Assassin. Just don't expect it to do anything new or exciting.

Hitman 2: Silent Assassin is the second game in the Hitman series. It follows the journey of a contract killer named 47 as he travels around the world, eliminating his target in order to save one of his few friends.

Hitman 2 is one of the few game that manage to do a disguise-based stealth right, with tons of disguises you are able to use all over the game. However, that does not make the game easier, as the AI in this game are capable of seeing through your disguise if you even act one bit suspicious (and some of them are even capable of seeing it from far away, as the ninja's from the Japan level can attest. Dem Psychic ninja). This makes sure that the game can be intense as well as satisfying when you do manage to beat the level with Silent Assassin rating.

This game also allows one to take multiple way to eliminate 47's targets. From disguising his way to the target, or going in with guns blazing high, there will be many ways one can do in this game, ensuring its replayability value.

reviewText:
Hitman 2 Silent Assassin is to my mind a true classic for me even though this game is now about 14 years old it is still an excellent game and a great source of entertainment. This game brings you into the world of Legendary Assassin Agent 47 who comes out of retirement and is plunged into the criminal underworld as the ulimate assassin all with you at the controls. The gameplay in this game is obviously quite dated by the standards of games today but in my opinion you should not let that deter you from buying or playing this game because the controls still feel great and are easy to learn and memorize.

This game possess great variety in the methods to which you conduct your assassination attempts throughout the various levels. The great thing about the Hitman series is that the game gives you alot of freedom in how your aproach it you are in no way stuck to a linear setup in the levels and as such this game grants you a great deal of replayability as you can choose to play the same missions many times but go about them in very different ways ranging from the coveted Silent Assassin rank or to other more brutal and straightfoward methods. In addition to this you can take lots of different routs and use different tools and scenario's to perform your hits.

With an exception level count of 20 missions which is the most in any Hitman game you will be playing this game for a considerable time even following a guide on how to go through this game still grants up to 15 hours play for just 1 playthrough but you could decide to take your time and study each map and try all the different methods which would great you up to 25 hours plus and that is just one playthrough you can do it a totally different way in another playtrhough.

Now this game is not perfect and there are a few negatives such as glitches that can imped you from getting the best rank in some levels but they dont always happen so they are not to bad and also the AI can be quite finicky and strange at times which can be frustrating but once you learn the pattens of this its really not a huge issue at all.

On another note i should bring up the outstanding soundtrack by composer Jesper Kyd who quite simply creates an amazing soundtrack for this game which so wonderfully helps to immerse you in this very fun game to my way of thinking soundtracks and game atmosphere are very important to a successful and enjoyable game experience and this game delivers that with flying colors. All in all i would highly recommend this game for those who are thinking about it its a true classic it may be old but it is excellent and still holds up well in todays gaming if you ask me you have to really think about what you are doing and there is alot of variety to keep it fresh i give it a solid 7.5/10

I think Silent Assassin is my favorite Hitman game. Maybe even more than Blood Money. reviewText:
A classic in every sense of the word. Originally released on the Super Nintendo by Mojang, Hitman 2 has seen many variations over the years. I'm happy to report that this is the definitive version, graphics rendered in beautiful 9000p resolution, breathtaking vistas running at an amazing 1500 fps, WOW. They've truly outdone themselves with this port.

For those of you unfamiliar to the Hitman franchise, you play as Agent 3.14159265358979323846264338327950 or Agent Pi for short. In your daily life as an assassin of the silent variety, you must take out high value targets while keeping a stable family. Be warned, this is not a game for the casual gamer. The game is a unique blend of a golf simulator, a Sims game and a first person shooter. When you start out, you will find yourself failing. A lot. You'll either mess up a hit and find your family murdered when you come home (Funnily enough, this scenario actually has a whole spin off dedicated to it known as Max Payne, I might review that some day) or you'll complete all of your hits but neglect personal needs and die of starvation. If you can get past the learning curve, you'll find a rich and rewarding experience full of many twists and turns. In my playthrough, my third born son, Alexander IV was diagnosed with lukemia. I had to spend all of the money I acquired from hits to pay for his medication and neglect my own needs for the highest quality cocaine. Yes, this game often requires you to make the difficult decisions such as : My wife is draining my wallet dry but she cuts the time it takes for me to disguise in half, should I really get rid of her?

All in all, this truly is a great game in every sense of the word. 1/10.

Silent Assassin isn't just the subtitle of this game - it's also the whole theme. Hitman 2 takes the social stealth element introduced by the first game to the next level - enemies who are familiar with a particular disguise are capable of seeing through it if you get too close to them or behave suspiciously, making your choice of disguise tactical. This makes levels far more tense and tactically complex, requiring more thought and planning on the part of the player to carry out hits in a clean way. The game also emphasizes cleanliness more - you get an end-of-mission rating that breaks down your activity, and if you get a perfect score (Silent assassin), you can get bonus weapons for use down the line. Whereas Codename 47 had several levels that encouraged combat on the part of the player, Silent Assassin has pushed the series far more clearly towards stealth and subtlety - and when the bullets do start flying, it's far more satisfying this time around. This game is still somewhat frustrating, but not nearly as much as the original - it's more polished in nearly every way, and the story is presented in a distinctly movie-like fashion, which suits it perfectly. Like it's predecessor, this game has a lot going on for those willing to put up with the occasional bad level or frustration - but not nearly as much as before. Also, this time there are mid-mission saves.

Silent Assassin isn't just the subtitle of this game - it's also the whole theme. Hitman 2 takes the social stealth element introduced by the first game to the next level - enemies who are familiar with a particular disguise are capable of seeing through it if you get too close to them or behave suspiciously, making your choice of disguise tactical. This makes levels far more tense and tactically complex, requiring more thought and planning on the part of the player to carry out hits in a clean way. The game also emphasizes cleanliness more - you get an end-of-mission rating that breaks down your activity, and if you get a perfect score (Silent assassin), you can get bonus weapons for use down the line. Whereas Codename 47 had several levels that encouraged combat on the part of the player, Silent Assassin has pushed the series far more clearly towards stealth and subtlety - and when the bullets do start flying, it's far more satisfying this time around. This game is still somewhat frustrating, but not nearly as much as the original - it's more polished in nearly every way, and the story is presented in a distinctly movie-like fashion, which suits it perfectly. Like it's predecessor, this game has a lot going on for those willing to put up with the occasional bad level or frustration - but not nearly as much as before. Also, this time there are mid-mission saves.

reviewText: This game is a classic. While it does show its age, it still holds up due to its great level design, story, and plethora of ways to assasinate your target. The soundtrack is also extremely good.
Classic

Note: I haven't played Hitman: Codename 47, so I don't know how the game's improved. Therefore, I won't be comparing the two games.
Note 2: Just because a category is in a Good list, doesn't mean that it doesn't also have some Bad in it that I haven't mentioned (I hope I've mentioned everything).

Good stuff
AI - The AI is smart, and acts as you would expect, though they do seem to be rather trigger-happy when seeing 47 run (even if they have no good reason too).
Bugginess - Haven't run into any bugs (that I know of).
Level design - Most levels have an interesting scenario in which to assassinate your target. Otherwise, they're about reaching the exit. The levels I least enjoyed are the no-target ones set in Japan. I know that they're there to show how much power and how well-protected the target is, but at least make it so that you don't have your ID checked every 100 metres. Also, in some levels, it's impossible to get Silent Assassin a rating.
Level variation - The levels are nicely varied, ranging from infiltrating a mansion to infiltrating a castle, attending a party that your target is hosting to sniping your targets at a meeting.
Mechanics - You play as a contract-killer, and your only goal is to kill your target (except for some other goals). This means that you decide how you want to complete your goal, allowing for open-ended gameplay, the level being the playground in which you can tinker with. The game also lets you find disguises (found either lying around or on incapacitated NPCs), letting you into restricted areas that aren't available as a civilian, and to be allowed to carry weapons (that fir with the disguise). Being too close to another person in the same outfit (e.g. being close to a guard whilst wearing a guard disguise) will make them suspicious, causing them to follow you, and if more suspicious, shoot at you, blowing your disguise permanently.
Music - Great soundtrack, the different tracks that play in the different locations make for some great atmosphere.
Performance - Since the graphics are less demanding, the game plays very smoothly, even on a low-end machine.
Replay value - There's another reason to want to replay levels, asides from just for fun or to try out new ways to take out your target. There's now a kind of base (I'm stretching the word here) to return to between missions, where you can collect and store weapons (which carry over between missions), or replay previous missions to get ones that you missed. You also get rewarded for completing a certain number of missions with the ranking 'Silent Assassin', which encourages stealth, though one of the rewards is a shotgun, so, uh, not very helpful sometimes.
Bad stuff
Story - The story is not very good when playing the game, but is much more interesting to read about on the wiki (Maybe the story just flew over my head. I think it did, actually). Just a standard 'save your hostage friend from the bad guys', but ends with a nice sequel-hook. The cutscenes are pretty well-made, and thankfully, the story isn't at all intrusive.
Visuals - The graphics haven't aged well, the player models very blocky looking.
Summary:
An overall great game, let down only by its graphics, and maybe the story, but not that much, due to it being out of the way. Gameplay is fun and tense, and the open levels allow for a variety of methods to get to your target.

Hitman 2: Silent Assassin is the second installment in the series, a game that showcased what the hitman formula was truly about - by correcting every single flaw of the first game and perfecting it to what we know and love today. To put it bluntly, this game excels in every area, except the AI department. Still, this only flaw doesn't really make itself noticed for most of the game; the only times where the enemy AI is a problem are the second and third mission of the Japanese chapter of the game, and that is only for players trying to achieve a high score - some may be put off from finishing the game because of them, but I highly recommend that you don't give up so easily. Anyway, now that the flaw(s) are out of the way, let's get to the good part. This game looked fantastic for it's time (not necessarily top-notch, but well above average), had a brilliant orchestral score (the same Jesper Kyd - the composer from the first game - is responsible again), a much-needed save system and also a new scoring system, which became a staple for the series ever since (depending on your performance on a level, the highest ranking you can achieve is Silent Assassin - this is where the game can be challenging, especially if you plan on collecting all weapons; also, the number of saves that are available depend on your difficulty setting - for the veterans, the only respectable option is the proffesional mode, which if I'm not mistaken doesn't allow any saves; the only exceptions are the bonus saves in some of the harder levels; oh, and did I mention that it makes the game harder by improving enemy AI?). I could go on forever explaining why I think this is one of the best games ever, but that wouldn't make for an entairtaining review now, would it? I'll only add that there's a ton of weapons to collect in this game (you can see them in your neat little shed), more missions than ever (this is by far the longest game in the franchise), more diversity than ever (this game takes 47 to Sicily, Russia, Japan, Malaysia, Afghanistan and India) and even the story is  lot more interesting this time around (although nothing can top Ortmeyer's speech from the first game). That's it. Now go and play this amazing game for yourself!
